## What are GBIF and OBIS?

::: {.columns .v-center-container}
::: {.column width="10%"}
{{< iconify icon-park international size=3x >}}

<br>

{{< iconify gala data size=3x >}}

<br>

{{< iconify pepicons-print people-circle size=3x >}}
:::

::: {.column width="90%"}
GBIF and OBIS are international initiatives that aim to provide open access to biodiversity occurrence data.

<br>

Although they are most well-known for their publishing platforms, and their role as data aggregators...

<br>

...both initiatives represent an investment from the international political community and a vibrant scientific community of nodes, publishers, and users of standards and practices.
:::
:::

## What are GBIF and OBIS?

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false

# Generate data holdings stats

library(dplyr)
library(httr2)

options(scipen=999)

# GBIF Stats
gbif_occ_ct <- rgbif::occ_count() %>% 
  scales::comma()

gbif_dataset_ct <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.gbif.org/v1/dataset/search?limit=0") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json() %>% 
  .[["count"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

gbif_publisher_ct <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.gbif.org/v1/organization?limit=0&isEndorsed=true") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json() %>% 
  .[["count"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

gbif_paper_ct <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.gbif.org/v1/literature/search?contentType=literature&literatureType=journal&relevance=GBIF_USED&peerReview=true&limit=0") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json() %>% 
  .[["count"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

# OBIS Stats
stats <- httr2::request(base_url = "https://api.obis.org/statistics") %>% 
  req_perform() %>% 
  resp_body_json()

obis_occ_ct <-  stats %>% 
  .[["records"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

obis_dataset_ct <- stats %>% 
  .[["datasets"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

obis_taxa_ct <- stats %>% 
  .[["species"]] %>% 
  scales::comma()

```

## What are GBIF and OBIS?

::: {style="font-size: 50%; text-align: center"}
Map of the GBIF and OBIS networks. Countries where there is at least one GBIF node are in blue. Yellow points represent OBIS nodes.
:::

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| message: false
#| warning: false
#| fig-align: center
#| out-width: "100%"
#| fig-alt: Map of the GBIF and OBIS networks.  Countries where there is at least one GBIF node are in blue.  Yellow points represent OBIS nodes.

# Generate Map of GBIF and OBIS nodes

library(dplyr)
library(rgbif)
library(robis)
library(ggplot2)

gbif_nodes <- rgbif::nodes(limit = 1000) %>% 
  .[["data"]] %>% 
  select(title, country)

obis_nodes <- robis::node() %>% 
  select(name, lon,lat) %>% 
  sf::st_as_sf(coords = c("lon", "lat"), crs = 4326)
  
countries <- rnaturalearth::ne_countries(returnclass = "sf")


ggplot(data = countries) +
  geom_sf(aes(fill = postal %in% gbif_nodes$country)) +
  geom_sf(
    data = obis_nodes,
    inherit.aes = FALSE,
    color = "black",
    fill = "#F0E442",
    shape = 21,
    size = 4
  ) +
  theme_classic() +
  theme(legend.position = "None") +
  coord_sf(xlim = c(-180, 180),
           ylim = c(-90, 90)) +
  scale_fill_manual(values = c("grey", "#56B4E9"))

```

## What are GBIF-US and OBIS-USA?

![](images/USGS_ID_green.png){height="75"} ![](images/IOOS_Emblem_Primary_B_RGB.jpg){height="75"} ![](images/NSF_Official_logo_High_Res_1200ppi.png){height="100"}

::: {style="font-size: 75%; text-align: left"}
USGS-SAS Biogeographic Science Branch manages the US nodes: GBIF-US and OBIS-USA.

-   represent US interests in the international initiatives
-   advise the US scientific community on biodiversity informatics, data, and standards
-   mobilize and synthesize data to enhance its FAIRness and relevance on national and international scales.
:::

## Why do we work with GBIF and OBIS?

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false}

::: {.columns .v-center-container}

::: {.column width="50%"}

![*Sparkly fountains need robust plumbing systems. <br>- Terry McConnell \(International Digital Twins of the Ocean Summit 2022\)*](images/67725_image_access_800/1_06_10_022012_image_access_800.jpg){fig-alt="https://ark.digitalcommonwealth.org/ark:/50959/r781wg156" height=300}
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

The US has been a voting participant in GBIF since 2001 and became an OBIS-USA node in 2005. 

<br>

The USGS is shepherding over two decades of investment in the robust plumbing needed for national and global biodiversity science and data.

:::

:::

:::

## How are GBIF and OBIS the same?

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="10%"}

{{< iconify openmoji whale size=3x >}}

:::

::: {.column width="90%"}

Both are active and energetic communities that develop, maintain, and promote standards and practices for biodiversity science and have been doing so for > 20 years

:::

:::

:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="10%"}

{{< iconify openmoji unlocked size=3x >}}

:::

::: {.column width="90%"}

Both promote open data and science, and publish massive amounts of standardized biological observations through their platforms

:::

:::

:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="10%"}

{{< iconify openmoji handshake-medium-dark-skin-tone-medium-skin-tone size=3x >}}

:::

::: {.column width="90%"}

Have signed a [letter of agreement](https://www.gbif.org/news/6M8YYYirX3bK57bHaIpd0U/ocean-biodiversity-information-system-and-gbif-update-and-expand-cooperation-agreement) in recognition that their respective communities will benefit from more streamlined ways of working together.  A stronger action plan is forthcoming.

:::

:::

:::

::: {.callout-note appearance="simple" icon=false}

::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="10%"}

{{< iconify openmoji clipboard size=3x >}}

:::

::: {.column width="90%"}

GBIF and OBIS are built on the same data and metadata standards, and share open-source tools

:::

:::

:::
